awd_titl_txt: Planning Grant: Bridging the STEM Gap - Enhancing STEM Education Using a Multitier Approach
awd_abstract_narration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities - Undergraduate program provides support for planning grants to study and assess comprehensive institutional efforts to increase the numbers of students and the quality of their preparation by strengthening science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) education and research. This project at South Carolina State University provides a strategic approach to redesigning foundational STEM courses to increase student success. The project is guided and informed by an on-going evaluation, as well as external and internal advisory committees. 

The project seeks to establish the STEM Recruitment, Retention, and Success Center to create an environment to guarantee STEM student success. The center will focus on STEM recruitment, retention and student service activities. Much of the planning activities involve creating the vision and the activities for this center to enhance STEM student retention by employing innovative teaching strategies in STEM gate-keeping courses, providing students with internships and research experiences, and preparing them for graduate school and the workforce. The project will pilot implementing active learning strategies in introductory Physics and Computer Science courses. Outreach activities with the Calhoun County School District and Orangeburg Calhoun Technical College will be conducted.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The specific goals and objectives of the Planning Grant: Bridging the STEM Gap - Enhancing STEM Education Using a Multitier Approach at South Carolina State University (SC State), the only public HBCU in South Carolina, project was to 1. Assemble the Internal and External Advisory Team; 2. Finalize the evaluation plan in consultation with the external advisor; 3. Strengthen the student mentoring plan; 4. Conduct outreach activities; 5. Implement active learning strategies in one course with at least two sections from Physics and Computer Science; 6. Create an online space.

 

This project was designed to have a positive impact on the recruitment, retention, and success of undergraduate students in the science, technology, mathematics, and engineering (STEM) disciplines at South Carolina State University.  The project involved a coordinated effort among academic departments in the College of Science, Technology, Engineering, Mathematics and Transportation (CSTEM-T); the Office of the Registrar, the Office of Student Success and Retention; and the Career Center at SCSU.  Additionally, the project involved partnerships and collaborations with STEM related industries across South Carolina and participation of K12 educators and students in local school districts. 

 

To accomplish the goals and related objectives of the project, the developers designed strategies to address project management, recruitment, and retention of participants; offered services designed to promote academic success; and implemented strategies designed to impact the larger community of the university.  A Student Recruitment, Retention, Succuss Center (SRRSC) was developed for daily operation of the project, and the SRRSC was equipped with computing resources (computer, printer/scanner, telephone, Internet, and others) needed for daily operation of the project. 

 

A management team structure that included an external and an internal project advisory team was put in place during the Fall 2019 semester and continued through spring 2022. Participants included faculty from academic departments in the CSMET and from the Retention, Recruitment and Student Success offices at SCSU.  The non-SCSU participants included K12 school administrators, community college administrators and representatives from industry.  During the 2019-2020 academic year, formal project meetings were held in August, September, November, and April.  There were few formal meetings of the management team held during 2020-2021 and 2021-2022 due to the COVID-19 disruption.

 

The project provided scholarships, mentoring, training, and professional development opportunities to forty (40) students from the CSTEM-T during the project period. The project also provided stipends to ten (10) SC State STEM faculty and six (6) K-12 for their participation  in series of workshops on (a) active learning concepts and their use in STEM courses and role of to the project during the project period. Active learning concepts such as flipped classroom, group learning, and others were implemented in selected Physics, Mathematics and Computer Science courses with promising results.

 

The project provided Participating faculty were surveyed in January 2020 and asked to reflect on their project experiences during Fall 2020.  The seven respondents to the survey indicated that they participated in the project as mentors, advisory board members and members of the management team. Their activities included program planning, implementation, etc.  Reportedly, the management team met frequently, several times a month being the norm. No survey was administered during 2021-2022.  Participating faculty provided written summaries of their experiences in the project.  

 

The project team published the project findings in various conferences and workshops such as American Society for Engineering Education (ASEE) Virtual Conference, American Association of Physics Teachers (AAPT), Conference for Industry Education Collaboration (CIEC), National Initiative for Cybersecurity Education (NICE) Conference, and CAE conference.  Also, to enhance the ongoing retention, recruitment, training, and placement activities, the institution initiated several cybersecurity education, research, outreach, awareness, and workforce development program. The workforce development program is focused on secure software development and is developed in collaboration with SC HBCUs and industry partners. The program is based on a ?Earn and Learn? model and titled as ?Employer Degree Apprenticeship Program on Secure Software Development?. This registered it with Department of Labor (DoL) -  (https://www.urban.org/press-releases/urban-institute-announces-launch-innovative-degree-based-apprenticeship-program-cybersecurity-south).

 

In summary, the project created a center, the SRRSC, that served as the central hub for activities, launched initiatives to impact student recruitment, student success in gate keeper courses, and provided enrichment and support/training for students and faculty.  The results with regard to course enhancements, were deemed as positive by faculty and students.  These enhancements were implemented in CSMET classes as well as K12 classes taught by partnering teachers.  The data show a positive impact on student engagement and performance.  The project resulted in the submission of an HBCU UP Implementation Grant Proposal in 2020. The proposal received a ?Competitive? rating although it was not funded.  The project team plans to revise and resubmit the proposal during 2022 cycle. 

 


Last Modified: 08/01/2022
Modified by: Nikunja K Swain
